summary: This document is a series of emails from whistleblower Christopher J. Dilorio to various SEC officials, judges, and others, appealing the denial of his 2015 whistleblower award claim. He alleges massive, ongoing securities fraud involving Knight Capital/Virtu Financial (NITE), money laundering through OTC market shells, and systemic corruption within the SEC and FINRA that obstructs investigations and protects criminal entities.

persons.name: Christopher J. Dilorio
persons.context: Author of the emails, alleging widespread securities fraud, money laundering, and SEC corruption related to Knight Capital/Virtu Financial and OTC market shells.

persons.name: Dougie Cifu
persons.context: CEO of Virtu Financial (VIRT/NITE), accused of lack of transparency and overseeing a core business of illegal naked shorting and money laundering facilitation.

persons.name: Jay Clayton
persons.context: Former SEC Chairman accused of corruption, obstruction, and failing to disclose conflicts related to his former firm Sullivan Cromwell's work for Knight Capital.

persons.name: Carl Hoecker
persons.context: SEC Inspector General accused of criminally obstructing investigations into Dilorio's allegations and obstructing Congressional oversight.

persons.name: Jared Fishman
persons.context: Attorney at Sullivan Cromwell, implicated in the Knight Capital bailout and alleged SEC corruption under Jay Clayton.

persons.name: Steve Schwarzman
persons.context: CEO of Blackstone, accused of being on the SEC's 'do not investigate list' and involved in the Knight Capital bailout and Kodak fraud.

persons.name: Barry Honig
persons.context: Investor associated with multiple alleged money laundering shells (Jaclin, GRQ Consultants) and linked to fraud cases mentioned by the SEC.

persons.name: Michael Farkas
persons.context: Described as a 'prolific Bag Man' involved with money laundering shells like SkyWay and Blink Charging (BLNK).

persons.name: Josh Sason
persons.context: Bag man associated with Hanover/Magna and multiple alleged frauds (NewLead, FreeSeas). Subject of an SEC complaint.

persons.name: Justin Keener
persons.context: Bag man associated with JMJ, barred by FINRA, and involved in money laundering shells like Blink Charging.

persons.name: Lara Shalov Mehraban
persons.context: SEC attorney in the New York office, accused of corruptly obstructing investigations to protect her former Paul Weiss colleague Dougie Cifu.

persons.name: Janey
persons.context: SEC official (likely in the Office of the Whistleblower) addressed in many emails, accused of not distributing Dilorio's information and facilitating obstruction.

persons.name: David Urban
persons.context: Trump campaign manager and board member of Virtu Financial and money laundering shell FSD Pharma (HUGE).

persons.name: Jason New
persons.context: Blackstone executive and board member of Eastman Kodak, involved in the alleged Kodak fraud and internal investigation cover-up.

persons.name: George Karfunkel
persons.context: Investor linked to Eastman Kodak, American Stock Transfer, and donations to Congregation Chemdas Yisroel, implicated in insider trading.

persons.name: Moses Marx
persons.context: Business associate of George Karfunkel, involved with United Equities/Commodities and Berkshire Bancorp.

persons.name: Dick Best
persons.context: Former FINRA official, later SEC Atlanta office director, accused of criminally obstructing investigation into Dilorio's claims related to a Brown Brothers Harriman AML case.

persons.name: Alex Ioffe
persons.context: CFO of Virtu Financial, formerly CFO of Interactive Brokers during period covered by an SEC AML complaint.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: Attorney mentioned in context of praising SEC work, linked to the Kamensky case.

persons.name: Gary Gensler
persons.context: SEC Chairman (addressed in emails), urged to investigate allegations regarding Virtu Financial and OTC markets.

connections.description: Dilorio is a whistleblower alleging the SEC criminally obstructed his tips, used his information without credit, and facilitated the frauds he reported.
Mehraban is a former colleague of Cifu from Paul Weiss, accused of obstructing investigations to protect him and Virtu Financial.
Both were at Sullivan Cromwell; Fishman worked on Knight Capital matters, and Clayton is accused of not disclosing this conflict at the SEC.
Blackstone, led by Schwarzman, was a key bailout participant for Knight Capital in 2012 and is accused of being protected from SEC investigation.
Both are implicated in overlapping money laundering shell networks (e.g., Jaclin shells, Blink Charging).
Both are described as 'bag men' involved in fraudulent convertible note schemes and money laundering shells.
Longtime business partners involved in United Equities and Berkshire Bancorp.
Urban is a board member of Virtu Financial.

events.title: Knight Capital Trading Glitch and Bailout
events.description: Knight Capital suffered a massive trading glitch, dropping its stock price. It was bailed out by a consortium including Blackstone, Jefferies, Goldman Sachs, and others with SEC facilitation.

events.title: Dilorio Files TCR on Knight Capital
events.description: Christopher Dilorio filed a Tip, Complaint, or Referral (TCR) with the SEC detailing allegations of illegal naked shorting and money laundering at Knight Capital.

events.title: Opco Award Application Filed
events.description: Dilorio filed a whistleblower award application related to the Opco case, which was preliminarily denied in 2020 after a 5-year wait.

events.title: Preliminary Denial of Opco Award
events.description: The SEC's Office of the Whistleblower issued a preliminary denial of Dilorio's Opco award claim, stating 'SEC staff never saw Mr. Dilorio's information'.

events.title: SEC Adopts 'Summary Disposition' Rule
events.description: The SEC adopted a new whistleblower rule (240.21F-18) allowing denial of awards if staff never saw the information, referred to by Dilorio as the 'Christopher J. Dilorio Rule'.

events.title: BLNK Pump and Dump
events.description: Blink Charging (BLNK), alleged to be a money laundering shell, issued a press release about charging station grants, causing a 27% stock spike without an 8-K filing, alleged to be a fraudulent pump and dump.

events.title: Kodak-DFC Loan Announcement
events.description: Eastman Kodak announced a $765 million loan from the U.S. International Development Finance Corporation (DFC) to produce pharmaceutical ingredients, leading to a massive stock pump and dump. Alleged to be a fraud involving Blackstone and Trump associates.

events.title: Virtu Financial Q1 2021 Earnings Call
events.description: Virtu Financial's earnings call where CEO Dougie Cifu faced pointed questions from sell-side analysts about lack of transparency and the trillions of OTC shares traded.

keyFacts: The whistleblower alleges the core business of Knight Capital/Virtu Financial (NITE) is illegal, abusive naked shorting of OTC market shells to facilitate money laundering, generating trillions in share volume.
The SEC is accused of systemic corruption: criminally obstructing investigations, protecting entities like NITE and Blackstone, and actively facilitating frauds while denying whistleblower awards.
A network of 'bag men' (e.g., Barry Honig, Michael Farkas, Josh Sason, Justin Keener) control numerous alleged money laundering shells that trade on the OTC markets.

The SEC adopted a new 'Summary Disposition' rule (240.21F-18) in 2020, which the whistleblower claims was created specifically to deny his award by allowing denial if staff 'never saw' the information.
High-profile figures like Steve Schwarzman (Blackstone), Jay Clayton, and Trump associates (David Urban, Jared Kushner's circle) are implicated in alleged frauds and SEC protection.
